question: A.01 [1.0 point] Attached is the applicable portion from the chart of the nuclides, what will Fe-60 decay into?

answers.feedback: Incorrect.  Reference: β- decay (n→p + β-) Fe57 (N-1, Z+1) Chart of the Nuclides
Incorrect.  Reference: β- decay (n→p + β-) Fe57 (N-1, Z+1) Chart of the Nuclides
Incorrect.  Reference: β- decay (n→p + β-) Fe57 (N-1, Z+1) Chart of the Nuclides

question: A.02 [1.0 point] A reactor is critical at 18.2 inches on a controlling blade. The controlling blade is inserted to a position of 17.9 inches. The reactivity removal during the insertion is 0.1%Δk/k. What is the differential rod worth?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 7.3. Differential position is at the midpoint (18.05) Δρ = 0.1%Δk/k Δx = 18.2 – 17.9 = 0.3 inche Differential rod worth (Δρ/in) = (Δρ)/(∆x) = 0.1%Δk/k /0.3 = 0.33%Δk/k at midpoint (18.05 inches)

Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 7.3. Differential position is at the midpoint (18.05) Δρ = 0.1%Δk/k Δx = 18.2 – 17.9 = 0.3 inche Differential rod worth (Δρ/in) = (Δρ)/(∆x) = 0.1%Δk/k /0.3 = 0.33%Δk/k at midpoint (18.05 inches)

Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 7.3. Differential position is at the midpoint (18.05) Δρ = 0.1%Δk/k Δx = 18.2 – 17.9 = 0.3 inche Differential rod worth (Δρ/in) = (Δρ)/(∆x) = 0.1%Δk/k /0.3 = 0.33%Δk/k at midpoint (18.05 inches)

Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 7.3. Differential position is at the midpoint (18.05) Δρ = 0.1%Δk/k Δx = 18.2 – 17.9 = 0.3 inche Differential rod worth (Δρ/in) = (Δρ)/(∆x) = 0.1%Δk/k /0.3 = 0.33%Δk/k at midpoint (18.05 inches)

question: A.03 [1.0 point] A reactor is subcritical with a Keff of 0.945. Which ONE of the following is the MINIMUM reactivity (∆K/K) that must be added to produce PROMPT criticality? Given βeff=0.0078

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: from k=-1 0.945 to criticality (k=1), the reactivity required from subcritical to critical is ∆ρ = (1-k)/k = 0.055/(0.945) ∆k/k = 0.582. From criticality to JUST prompt, ∆ρ = βeff is needed. Therefore, the minimum reactivity required to produce prompt criticality is 0.0582 ∆k/k +0.0078∆k/k = 0.066 ∆k/k

Incorrect. Reference: from k=-1 0.945 to criticality (k=1), the reactivity required from subcritical to critical is ∆ρ = (1-k)/k = 0.055/(0.945) ∆k/k = 0.582. From criticality to JUST prompt, ∆ρ = βeff is needed. Therefore, the minimum reactivity required to produce prompt criticality is 0.0582 ∆k/k +0.0078∆k/k = 0.066 ∆k/k

Correct. Reference: from k=-1 0.945 to criticality (k=1), the reactivity required from subcritical to critical is ∆ρ = (1-k)/k = 0.055/(0.945) ∆k/k = 0.582. From criticality to JUST prompt, ∆ρ = βeff is needed. Therefore, the minimum reactivity required to produce prompt criticality is 0.0582 ∆k/k +0.0078∆k/k = 0.066 ∆k/k

Incorrect. Reference: from k=-1 0.945 to criticality (k=1), the reactivity required from subcritical to critical is ∆ρ = (1-k)/k = 0.055/(0.945) ∆k/k = 0.582. From criticality to JUST prompt, ∆ρ = βeff is needed. Therefore, the minimum reactivity required to produce prompt criticality is 0.0582 ∆k/k +0.0078∆k/k = 0.066 ∆k/k

question: A.05 [1.0 point] The reactor is critical at 500 watts. A control rod is withdrawn, adding a positive reactivity of $0.25. Which ONE of the following will be the stable reactor period as a result of this reactivity insertion? Given beta effective = 0.0078

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Reactivity added = $0.25 or $0.25 x0.0078= 0.00195 ∆k/k τ = (β-ρ)/λeff*ρ   =  0.0078 - 0.00195   = 30 seconds     (0.1) (0.00195)
Correct. Reference: Reactivity added = $0.25 or $0.25 x0.0078= 0.00195 ∆k/k τ = (β-ρ)/λeff*ρ   =  0.0078 - 0.00195   = 30 seconds     (0.1) (0.00195)
Incorrect. Reference: Reactivity added = $0.25 or $0.25 x0.0078= 0.00195 ∆k/k τ = (β-ρ)/λeff*ρ   =  0.0078 - 0.00195   = 30 seconds     (0.1) (0.00195)
Incorrect. Reference: Reactivity added = $0.25 or $0.25 x0.0078= 0.00195 ∆k/k τ = (β-ρ)/λeff*ρ   =  0.0078 - 0.00195   = 30 seconds     (0.1) (0.00195)

question: A.06 [1.0 point, 0.25 each] Identify whether each of the following conditions will INCREASE or DECREASE the shutdown margin of a reactor.

answers.answer: a. Building up a Xenon peak in the reactor core.
answers.feedback: INCREASE. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, NPRT, Vol. 2, Module 4, EO 3.6, p.28

answers.answer: b. Inserting the Boron experiment to the reactor core.
answers.feedback: INCREASE. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, NPRT, Vol. 2, Module 4, EO 3.6, p.28

answers.answer: c. Removing a control rod from the reactor core.
answers.feedback: DECREASE. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, NPRT, Vol. 2, Module 4, EO 3.6, p.28

answers.answer: d. Increasing moderator temperature (assume negative temperature coefficient).
answers.feedback: INCREASE. Reference: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, NPRT, Vol. 2, Module 4, EO 3.6, p.28

question: A.11 [1.0 point] If the multiplication factor, k, is increased from 0.80 to 0.95, the amount of reactivity added is:

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) (0.95-0.80) /(0.95*0.80) = 0.197
Incorrect. Reference: ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) (0.95-0.80) /(0.95*0.80) = 0.197
Incorrect. Reference: ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) (0.95-0.80) /(0.95*0.80) = 0.197
Incorrect. Reference: ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) (0.95-0.80) /(0.95*0.80) = 0.197

question: A.12 [1.0 point] The reactor is critical and increasing in power. Power has increased from 200 kW to 400 kW in 10 seconds. How long will it take at this rate for power to increase from 400 kW to 1 MW?

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: P = Poet/T      400 kW = 200 kW* e 10 sec/T      T = 14.4 sec    1000 kW = 400 kW e (t/14.4) t = 13.2 sec
Incorrect. Reference: P = Poet/T      400 kW = 200 kW* e 10 sec/T      T = 14.4 sec    1000 kW = 400 kW e (t/14.4) t = 13.2 sec
Incorrect. Reference: P = Poet/T      400 kW = 200 kW* e 10 sec/T      T = 14.4 sec    1000 kW = 400 kW e (t/14.4) t = 13.2 sec
Incorrect. Reference: P = Poet/T      400 kW = 200 kW* e 10 sec/T      T = 14.4 sec    1000 kW = 400 kW e (t/14.4) t = 13.2 sec

question: A.14 [1.0 point] A reactor is decreasing with a -80 second period shortly after shutdown. What is the time for power decreasing by a factor of 5?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: P/P0 = e-t/τ ln(1/5) = - (t)/(-80sec) Time (t) = ln (0.2) × -80 sec = 129 seconds
Incorrect. Reference: P/P0 = e-t/τ ln(1/5) = - (t)/(-80sec) Time (t) = ln (0.2) × -80 sec = 129 seconds
Correct. Reference: P/P0 = e-t/τ ln(1/5) = - (t)/(-80sec) Time (t) = ln (0.2) × -80 sec = 129 seconds
Incorrect. Reference: P/P0 = e-t/τ ln(1/5) = - (t)/(-80sec) Time (t) = ln (0.2) × -80 sec = 129 seconds

question: A.15 [1.0 point] If a source strength is 5000 neutrons per second (N/sec) and it produces the stable neutron count rate of 20000 N/sec. What is a multiplication factor?
A.16 [1.0 point] The reactor is on a constant period. Which ONE of the following changes in reactor power would take the SHORTEST time?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e t/τ   Ln(P/P0) = t/τ   Since you are looking for which would take the shortest time it is obvious to the most casual of observers that the ratio P/P0 must be the smallest value.

Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e t/τ   Ln(P/P0) = t/τ   Since you are looking for which would take the shortest time it is obvious to the most casual of observers that the ratio P/P0 must be the smallest value.

Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e t/τ   Ln(P/P0) = t/τ   Since you are looking for which would take the shortest time it is obvious to the most casual of observers that the ratio P/P0 must be the smallest value.

Correct. Reference: P = P0 e t/τ   Ln(P/P0) = t/τ   Since you are looking for which would take the shortest time it is obvious to the most casual of observers that the ratio P/P0 must be the smallest value.

question: A.19 [1.0 point] A reactor is subcritical with k-effective of 0.9. If a reactor operator makes a mistake by removing the control blade worth of 0.01 Δk/k out of the reactor core. Which ONE of the following best describes the reactor kinetic if removing the control blade?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: From k =0.9 to critical (k=1) the reactivity needed is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) (1.0-0.90)/(1.0*0.90) = 0.10 Δk/k By adding a worth of 0.01 Δk/k (even ρ > β-eff ), a reactor is still subcritical because 0.01 Δk/k << 0.10 Δk/k. Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.2

answers.answer: b. Super critical, Keff =1 and ρ < β-eff
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: From k =0.9 to critical (k=1) the reactivity needed is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) (1.0-0.90)/(1.0*0.90) = 0.10 Δk/k By adding a worth of 0.01 Δk/k (even ρ > β-eff ), a reactor is still subcritical because 0.01 Δk/k << 0.10 Δk/k. Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.2

answers.answer: c. Prompt critical, Keff > 1 and ρ > β-eff
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: From k =0.9 to critical (k=1) the reactivity needed is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) (1.0-0.90)/(1.0*0.90) = 0.10 Δk/k By adding a worth of 0.01 Δk/k (even ρ > β-eff ), a reactor is still subcritical because 0.01 Δk/k << 0.10 Δk/k. Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.2

Correct. Reference: From k =0.9 to critical (k=1) the reactivity needed is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) (1.0-0.90)/(1.0*0.90) = 0.10 Δk/k By adding a worth of 0.01 Δk/k (even ρ > β-eff ), a reactor is still subcritical because 0.01 Δk/k << 0.10 Δk/k. Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.2

question: QUESTION A.20 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following describes the term PROMPT JUMP?

answers.answer: a. A reactor is subcritical at negative 80-second period
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: b. A reactor has attained criticality on prompt neutrons alone
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: c. The instantaneous change in power level due to inserting a control blade
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: d. The instantaneous change in power level due to withdrawing a control blade
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.
